The oil and gas industry isn't winning catering to ESG feels. They're now "greedy price gougers". Bitcoin miners will suffer the same fate if they try to posture that they're "saving lives". They're taking advantage of economic incentives, which is a good thing. Own it.
People will find out about the handsome profits and call bullshit on the "saving lives" meme.
Framing matters.
The real narrative should be "incompetent energy policy built on virtue signaling is putting millions of lives at risk."

Bitcoin can certainly help by incentivizing the build out of grid capacity above what anyone could ever imagine peak demand to be, but to act like they are acting virtuously when they are turning off because they'll make more money or lock in a lower rate is the wrong approach.

Instead of taking victory laps about "bitcoin miners saving lives" (which isn't what is happening), people who are passionate about bitcoin mining and its place within energy systems should be leaning into the piss poor state of grid systems in the US.

@fewture @w_s_bitcoin @AndreiBehjan @ChartsBtc IIRC most nodes keep blockchain forks in-memory when a reorganization occurs, so a fork that is of a size greater than the available RAM on systems would likely cause the node process to fail due to an out of memory error.

@w_s_bitcoin @AndreiBehjan @ChartsBtc Would human node operators notice? Definitely. But the nodes just follow the rules.  From a practical standpoint, doing such a long-range reorg would likely crash most nodes. But it's still a valid theoretical attack.
@AndreiBehjan @w_s_bitcoin @ChartsBtc Sounds like you need to learn more about what nodes actually guarantee with regard to validity.  https://t.co/b6G4m6kWLQ

@AndreiBehjan @w_s_bitcoin @ChartsBtc To be clear, you "mine privately" without broadcasting until you have completed hashing the full blockchain fork you want to reorganize the main chain, then you broadcast it.  You still have to follow the validity rules, but the main goal is that your chain has more total PoW.

@RandallGilberd I think I have one chart regarding distribution of balances across addresses. I general I try not to lean too much on "on-chain analytics" that claim to identify wallets / entities given that they use heuristics that are often opaque. It's educated guesswork.

@w_s_bitcoin @ChartsBtc When you're mining privately to perform a long range reorganization of the blockchain, that's less of an issue because you have more discretion into what the timestamps are of the blocks and thus how the difficulty adjusts.

6/ @enzymefinance's competitors can be grouped into two categories: active and passive management.  On the active side, @dHedgeOrg operates similarly to Enzyme, with its ‚ÄúPools" product.  On the passive side, @iearnfinance uses automated smart contracts to seek out opportunities.  https://t.co/pMSiDwJwdh
5/ $MLN is @enzymefinance's Ethereum-based, ERC-20 utility token.  $MLN's main uses are for the payment of fees and to incentivize network participants.  https://t.co/a0XyfI9qia

4/ @enzymefinance Vaults can interact with 17 DeFi protocols on #Ethereum, allowing for more complex trading and investing strategies than simply buying and holding.  This feature set bodes well for future use cases for crypto investors, DAO treasuries, and portfolio managers

3/ Once a Vault is created, a user deposits capital and receives ERC-20 tokens representing their share of the Vault.  Users can later redeem these ERC-20 tokens for the pro rata amount of AUM they are entitled to.

2/ @enzymefinance functions around its flagship feature, "Vaults".  Vaults are on-chain investment structures.  Any individual can create a vault, customize its parameters, and select an investing or trading strategy.

1/ Decentralized asset management may stand to benefit from CeFi‚Äôs failure.  @enzymefinance is leading this charge as the largest on-chain active asset management platform by TVL.üßµ  https://t.co/mCVqvqHisn

10/ For an in-depth look at @Cardano, its tech, the state of the Cardano ecosystem, $ADA's tokenomics, and the competitive landscape, check out the full report for FREE from @redvelvetzip.  https://t.co/8uv8SI844y

9/ @Cardano shared the same fate as most others with a 65% drop in market cap through Q3 this year.  Cardano‚Äôs goal in the near future will be to catch up to established ecosystems and take some market share.  https://t.co/8w2klF1Tim

8/ ~State of Cardano Ecosystem  @Cardano experienced a surge in Q1 2022 DeFi activity, with daily transactions settling at about 60K in Q3.  Cardano‚Äôs DeFi TVL was ~$78M at the end of Q3 2022 with a market cap of ~$14.8B, giving Cardano a Mcap/TVL ratio of ~190.  https://t.co/BMDOZvVWJw

7/ ~Tokenomics  $ADA, the native token on @Cardano, is used for P2P transactions, security, and gas fees.  The max supply of ADA is 45B, with 35B $ADA (78%) currently in supply.  https://t.co/NrYyV1u0yU

6/ ~Technology cont.  @Cardano also differs from account-based transaction models in that it has multi-asset support.  All tokens, both fungible and non-fungible, share almost all the functionality as $ADA.

5/ ~Technology cont.  @Cardano's uses a novel version of UTXO called the extended UTXO (eUTXO).  To avoid concurrency risks, dapp developers must find ways to batch transactions to allow simultaneous UTXO interactions within the same block (e.g. @SundaeSwap, @MELD_Defi).

4/ ~Technology cont.  @Cardano's modular design operates on two separate layers, the Cardano Settlement Layer (CSL), optimized for value transfer, and the Cardano Computing Layer (CCL), optimized for data storage.

3/ ~Technology  @Cardano was an early adopter of Proof-of-Stake and modularity.  Ouroboros, Cardano‚Äôs Proof-of-Stake (PoS) consensus mechanism, allows users to delegate their $ADA to a stake pool operator and earn rewards while still retaining ownership of their tokens.

2/ ~Background  @Cardano's development started in 2015 at the hands of @IOHK_Charles and Jeremy Wood.  Cardano is now supported by three entities (@InputOutputHK, @Cardano_CF, @emurgo_i0) with a roadmap consisting of five phases: Byron, Shelley, Goguen, Basho, and Voltaire.

1/ Conceived with the goal of solving security, scalability, and sustainability problems, @cardano has taken a calculated approach to development, putting functionalities through rigorous academic peer review before production.üßµ  https://t.co/rVJuxe9ybi
https://t.co/qQpNzo9lK9

@cafreiman It seems more broadly true that groups that really emphasize being warm and fluffy and egalitarian internally often have a dark side of being unwelcoming to outsiders.  I wonder what the exceptions are and what we can learn from them.

Another pattern I despise is insisting on a really important difference in meaning to words that sound like synonyms.  "complex vs complicated" "money vs currency" "decentralized vs distributed"  No. Stop. Let them be synonyms, use more specific words that clarify the difference.

Often when a word has a confusing meaning, the most viable path is to just stop using it. "Fortnightly" is too obscure; I'd probably just say "twice per month" and "every 2 months" (eg. "your salary is $2500 twice per month") directly.
Recommend this.  Giving money directly to the poorest people in the world is a simple effective way of greatly improving people's lives that we can all get behind.

@alfegaly Pragmatic libertarians should accept that governments having budgets is good, because they can spend it on welfare programs which substitute economically ugly and intrusive stuff like rent control, rationing, strict labor regulation, etc  Land value tax helps with this.

@alfegaly Land value tax is one of the forms of taxation that requires the *least* authoritarian/intrusive compliance infrastructure.  It avoids taxing transactions entirely, and it's only looking at land, not improvements, so you don't even need to peek into each person's property.

6/ The 118th Congress has a historic opportunity before it to ensure the US remains an innovation leader for decades to come. We hope it‚Äôs one they take.

5/ Changing the status quo is never easy but I believe that the will to act exists. The building blocks for regulation have already been introduced, and we have a chance to get this right for millions of Americans who already are - and will continue to be - interested in crypto.

4/ Singapore, the EU, Brazil, and Japan all have crypto frameworks - and the UK is well ahead of the US. But the lack of coordinated standards globally (or any in the US) continues to push business to countries w/ lower regulatory bars - w/ sometimes catastrophic results (FTX).

3/ No bill is perfect and there likely never will be one that satisfies everyone. But perfect shouldn‚Äôt be the enemy of progress - these proposals provide more than a starting point for debate in this new Congress. The stakes couldn‚Äôt be higher.

2/ We‚Äôre not working with a blank slate. Prior bills have tried to address everything from stablecoins and CEXs (RFIA and DCEA); clearer definitions of what constitutes a digital asset security (Securities Clarity Act); safe harbors (Clarity for Digital Tokens Act) and more.

1/ support for regulation is bipartisan & bicameral. Leaders like @PatrickMcHenry, @CongressmanGT, @RepTomEmmer, @RitchieTorres, @RoKhanna, @SenStabenow, @JohnBoozman, @SenGillibrand, @SenLummis, @CoryBooker have publicly supported blockchain and recognized the need for clarity.

Today is the first day of the 118th Congress. While prior efforts at regulatory clarity for crypto in the US have stalled, I am cautiously optimistic that 2023 is the year we will (finally!) see a breakthrough. A thread on why‚Ä¶
